Package ulb.infof307.g02.gui.controller

Interface ControllerNavigator

All Known Implementing Classes:
AutochefController, ConnectionToAccountController, Controller, CreateAccountController, RecipeConfigureController, RecipeInfoController, RecipeListController, ScheduleConfigureController, ScheduleInfoController, ShoppingListConfigureController, ShoppingListInfoController, ShoppingListListController, ShoppingListStoreInfoController, StoreConfigureController, StoreInfoController, StoreListController
public interface ControllerNavigator
This interface is used by all the controllers to "go" back and forth between different view. In reality, it displays the "next view", i.e. the one associated to the controller given in argument.

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type
    Method
    Description
    <M extends SQLModel<M>, T extends Controller>
    void
    goTo(Function<M,T> nextController, M model)
    Go to the next "view/controller" association, this one is used when the controller require a model to display in the view.
    <T extends Controller>
    void
    goTo(Supplier<T> nextController)
    Go to the next "view/controller" association, this one is used for controllers that does not require a model.

  • Method Details

    • goTo

      <T extends Controller> void goTo(Supplier<T> nextController)
      Go to the next "view/controller" association, this one is used for controllers that does not require a model.
      Type Parameters:
      T - we ensure that the constructor is associated to a controller ("supplies a controller")
      Parameters:
      nextController - : the constructor method of the controller associated to the view we want to display

    • goTo

      <M extends SQLModel<M>, T extends Controller> void goTo(Function<M,T> nextController, M model)
      Go to the next "view/controller" association, this one is used when the controller require a model to display in the view. For example, when modifying a recipe
      Type Parameters:
      M - we ensure that we receive a SQLModel, letting us use SQLModel methods such as getId() or getName()
      T - we ensure that the constructor is associated to a controller ("supplies a controller when given a SQLModel in argument")
      Parameters:
      nextController - : the constructor method of the controller associated to the view we want to display
      model - : the model needed by the controller to properly display information or execute
